title: Theodore Friedman, Lawyer Who Triumphed Over Disbarment, Dies at 94
description: A zealous New York personal injury lawyer, he won many news-making cases before his professional fall. He was reinstated after 16 years.
content:
The negligence lawyer Theodore H. Friedman in 1994, the year his license to practice was revoked after he was accused of professional misconduct. It was restored in 2010.

A zealous New York personal injury lawyer, he won many news-making cases before his professional fall. He was reinstated after 16 years.

Theodore H. Friedman, a high-flying negligence lawyer whose ferocious advocacy ground opponents down, and who was disbarred for unethical conduct — but who won back his law license 16 years later by advocating just as ferociously for himself — died on July 30 at his home in Inverness, Calif., north of San Francisco. He was 94. The cause was heart disease, said Benjamin Meyers, a law associate of Mr. Friedman’s. Before his license to practice was revoked in 1994, Mr. Friedman was one of New York’s most prominent personal injury lawyers in the 1970s and ’80s. He was known for doggedly raising the same objections at trial after being overruled, for dressing down judges and opposing lawyers, and for reminding fellow officers of the court that he had a Harvard law degree and they did not. He once told Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, “You’re either corrupt or ignorant, and it doesn’t matter which.” Mr. Friedman’s aggressiveness won clients big payments, including $11 million for the family of the singer-songwriter Harry Chapin, who was killed in a car accident, and $854,000 for Virginia O’Hare, whose plastic surgeon left her navel off-center during a tummy tuck.

“Teddy was born in the Bronx, and he never forgot it,” William M. Kimball, a lawyer who lost several cases to Mr. Friedman, told The New York Times in 1994. “He had one of those aggressive inferiority complexes that propel people to considerable distances and considerable heights.” The author Malcolm Gladwell interviewed Mr. Friedman for a 2008 book, “Outliers,” that looked at how some people achieve extraordinary success in life. Mr. Friedman’s disbarment exposed an underside to his turn-it-to-11 style of lawyering. Accused of 23 counts of professional misconduct — including intentional dishonesty, filing a false affidavit and soliciting false testimony from a witness — he lost his law license after a special referee affirmed 14 of the charges. He was disbarred by the Appellate Division of the First Department, a state court that oversees civil and criminal appeals in Manhattan and the Bronx.

His disbarment was seen by some in the legal community as unfair, by others as a comeuppance for sleaze, and by still others as a cautionary tale about the limits of overzealous advocacy. In his defense, Mr. Friedman submitted 67 letters attesting to his good character from prominent jurists, including the chief judge of New York’s Court of Appeals, and from the journalists Calvin Trillin, Murray Kempton and Mr. Zion. The sheaf of letters, The Times reported at the time, portrayed Mr. Friedman and his wife, Eve Preminger, a judge on New York Surrogate’s Court, “as a lively, sought-after couple in social circles on the Upper West Side and Fire Island.” Mr. Kempton, in a 1988 Newsday column, had hailed Mr. Friedman as an avenging angel for suing the city on behalf of wronged citizens, including a man who fell to his death in an elevator shaft of a city-owned building. “Life in New York is a succession of officially tolerated outrages upon the unwary, and there is no one to punish those responsible except the negligence lawyer,” Mr. Kempton thundered. In 1962, Mr. Friedman married Ms. Preminger, a niece of the movie director Otto Preminger, who had been one of the few women in her graduating class two years earlier at Columbia Law School. She died two weeks after her husband, on Aug. 12, after 63 years of marriage.

It was Mr. Friedman’s suit against New York City in the case of the elevator death that compounded his own legal troubles. He was indicted by the Manhattan district attorney’s office on a charge of attempting to bribe a witness in the case. A jury acquitted him in 1988, but his ethics came under the scrutiny of the disciplinary committee of the Manhattan appellate court. The committee folded a second case into its investigation. In that case, from 1982, Mr. Friedman had been accused of disobeying a federal judge’s order not to give a document to the jury as it deliberated. The judge in that case, Pierre N. Leval, found that Mr. Friedman “surreptitiously included” the document for the jury anyway and lied about it in a sworn statement. Both ethics cases were investigated by the special state court referee, Donald J. Sullivan, who wrote that Mr. Friedman had become “consumed with the will to win at any price.” Mr. Sullivan recommended that Mr. Friedman’s law license be suspended for two years. But the five-judge Appellate Division overruled him, voting unanimously to disbar Mr. Friedman.

Theodore Herzl Friedman was born on May 3, 1931, the younger of two children of Avram and Mary (Kerewsky) Friedman, both of whom were born in Ukraine. His mother was a garment worker, union organizer and member of the Communist Party. His father was a Zionist who moved to the British Mandate of Palestine and then immigrated to the United States to further his education. Ted, as he was known, graduated from the competitive Bronx High School of Science and in 1953 from the University of Michigan; he helped pay for college by working in auto factories. He received a law degree from Harvard in 1956. He is survived by two daughters, Sarah Solomon and Wendy Futterman, and five grandchildren. In addition to his home in Inverness, he had a residence in Manhattan. Mr. Friedman, who once belonged to a club for negligence lawyers who had won seven-figure verdicts, campaigned to regain his license and means of support with the same single-mindedness he had used in advocating on behalf of clients. He filed three petitions for reinstatement to the bar — in 1999, 2003 and 2006 — but the Appellate Division denied each one.
summary: Theodore H. Friedman, a high-profile New York personal injury lawyer who was disbarred for unethical conduct, passed away at 94 from heart disease. His license to practice was revoked in 1994 after he was accused of professional misconduct, but was restored in 2010 after 16 years. Known for his aggressive advocacy, Friedman won many news-making cases and won clients including $11 million for the family of singer-songwriter Harry Chapin and $854,000 for Virginia O’Hare. His disbarment was seen by some as unfair, others as a comeuppance for sleaze, and as a cautionary tale about the limits of overzealous advocacy.
shortSummary: Theodore H. Friedman, a renowned New York personal injury lawyer, died at 94 after successfully defending his profession against disbarment for unethical conduct.
argos_summary: Theodore H. Friedman, a high‑profile New York negligence lawyer known for his aggressive advocacy, was disbarred in 1994 after 23 counts of professional misconduct, including filing false affidavits and attempting to bribe a witness. He fought to regain his license, filing petitions in 1999, 2003, and 2006, before finally being reinstated in 2010. Friedman’s career included landmark victories such as an $11 million settlement for Harry Chapin’s family and a $854,000 award for a plastic‑surgery malpractice case, but his reputation was marred by accusations of unethical behavior and a controversial indictment. He died on July 30, 2025, at age 94 in Inverness, California, after a long legal battle and a career that exemplified both extraordinary success and the limits of overzealous advocacy.
